ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I acquired more skills for reading and interpreting Akkadian literature from the cuneiform.
Greater understanding of the cuneiform writing system and knowledge of Akkadian grammar and conventions.

Developed skills in reading and interpreting Akkadian texts, grammar and script. I also developed my knowledge of Akkadian vocabulary, as well as gained more insight into the history of both scholarship on Akkadian texts and of the civilizations in which these texts were written.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: texts were interesting, I enjoyed the close reading of seminal (and not so seminal) works
Weaknesses: more secondary literature would have been useful,

The texts used were excellent and going into depth when reading the texts was helpful. More even coverage of the texts and more interactive assignments (eg submitted translations or analyses of parts of texts) would make a great course even better.
The course is very helpful in developing skills in Akkadian and in the background of texts. The weakness is only that the number of texts we were able to read was fairly small

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if they wanted to continue studying Akkadian.
Yes, but only if the student had at least some background in the language and was interested in developing that further, due to the level of difficulty.
